registry_purpose: Centralized schema governance for multi-sector critical infrastructure knowledge graph

4_labels.description: Core nodes with sector + type + function + monitoring

5_labels.description: Enhanced nodes with additional property or ontology labels

7_labels.description: Complex nodes with SAREF standard compliance

8_labels.description: Health monitoring nodes with maximum label complexity

Measurement.description: Energy measurement nodes tracking values across transmission systems

Device.description: Energy devices including EnergyDevice and distributed energy resources

Property.description: Energy properties tracking device characteristics and specifications

Asset.description: Physical energy assets including DERs, transmission lines, substations

Control.description: Control and management systems (EMS, NERC CIP compliance)

VULNERABLE_TO.description: Security vulnerability relationships mapping attack surfaces

HAS_ENERGY_PROPERTY.description: Links devices to their energy-specific properties

CONTROLLED_BY_EMS.description: Links devices to Energy Management Systems

COMPLIES_WITH_NERC_CIP.description: Compliance relationships with NERC CIP standards

CONNECTED_TO_GRID.description: Links distributed energy resources to power grid

Energy_Distribution.description: Distribution network nodes for local power delivery and control

Energy_Generation.description: Generation source nodes for renewable and distributed energy

ENERGY.compliance_focus: NERC CIP standards with SAREF ontology extension
ENERGY.security_emphasis: High - vulnerability mapping dominant relationship type

HAS_MEASUREMENT.description: Devices and processes generate measurement data

ROUTES_THROUGH.description: Traffic routing paths through network devices

Process.description: Data processing workflows, backup operations, authentication flows, API management, CI/CD pipelines

common_label_patterns.description: Universal label patterns appearing in both Water and Energy sectors

components: Level 1: NodeType (Device, Measurement, Property, Vulnerability, etc.)
Level 4: Monitoring status (Monitoring, Legacy, Decommissioned, etc.)

most_common_energy_patterns.pattern_type: Standard pattern for distribution devices with monitoring

required_node_types.description: Eight core node types present in both sectors with consistent definitions

Property.definition: Qualitative or derived attribute of an entity

ThreatActor.definition: Entity that poses a security threat
water_examples: Not explicitly modeled in water patterns
ThreatActor.sector_applicability: Primarily Energy sector, optional for Water

relationship_types.description: Common relationship types across both sectors

universal_relationships.description: Device produces or is associated with measurements
Device is susceptible to a vulnerability
universal_relationships.note: Dominant relationship type in both sectors

universal_relationships.description: Device is manufactured by a specific vendor
Device communicates using a specific protocol
Device is part of a subsystem

ENERGY.description: Links devices to Energy Management Systems

multi_label_rules.description: Rules for label assignment per node across sectors
multi_label_rules.reasoning: Balanced between expressiveness and query performance

quality_metrics.coverage: All nodes must have minimum 4 labels
quality_metrics.consistency: Same entity type should have similar label counts (+/- 1 label)
quality_metrics.performance: Query performance optimal at 5-6 labels per node

gold_standard_metrics.description: Target metrics for sector graph completeness based on Water and Energy examples

nodes_per_sector.reasoning: Both sectors fall within target range

measurement_nodes.rationale: Measurements are most frequent entity type in operational systems

device_nodes.rationale: Devices are core infrastructure; count varies by sector complexity

relationship_density.rationale: High connectivity for security vulnerability tracking

vulnerability_relationships.rationale: Security tracking is dominant relationship type in critical infrastructure

cross_sector_query_patterns.description: Common query patterns applicable to both Water and Energy sectors

pattern_1_device_vulnerability_chain.name: Find all vulnerable devices
pattern_1_device_vulnerability_chain.cypher_template: MATCH (d:Device)-[:VULNERABLE_TO]->(v:Vulnerability) WHERE v.severity = 'Critical' RETURN d, v
pattern_1_device_vulnerability_chain.water_use_case: Identify water treatment plants vulnerable to critical CVEs
pattern_1_device_vulnerability_chain.energy_use_case: Identify power generation systems vulnerable to critical CVEs

pattern_2_measurement_anomaly_detection.name: Find measurements outside normal range
pattern_2_measurement_anomaly_detection.cypher_template: MATCH (m:Measurement)-[:MEASURED_BY]->(d:Device) WHERE m.value > m.max OR m.value < m.min RETURN d, m
pattern_2_measurement_anomaly_detection.water_use_case: pH levels outside safe drinking water range
pattern_2_measurement_anomaly_detection.energy_use_case: Voltage levels outside nominal operating range

pattern_3_compliance_mapping.name: Map devices to applicable standards
pattern_3_compliance_mapping.cypher_template: MATCH (d:Device)-[:GOVERNED_BY]->(s:Standard) WHERE s.sector = $sector RETURN d, COLLECT(s.name)
pattern_3_compliance_mapping.water_use_case: Water system compliance with EPA and AWWA standards
pattern_3_compliance_mapping.energy_use_case: Power system compliance with NERC CIP and IEEE standards

pattern_4_vendor_ecosystem.name: Map vendor impact across infrastructure
pattern_4_vendor_ecosystem.cypher_template: MATCH (v:Vendor)<-[:MANUFACTURED_BY]-(d:Device)-[:VULNERABLE_TO]->(vuln:Vulnerability) RETURN v.name, COUNT(DISTINCT d), COUNT(DISTINCT vuln)

pattern_5_subsector_distribution.name: Analyze node distribution across subsectors
pattern_5_subsector_distribution.cypher_template: MATCH (n) WHERE n:WATER OR n:ENERGY RETURN labels(n), COUNT(n) ORDER BY COUNT(n) DESC

pattern_6_protocol_security.name: Assess protocol security across devices
pattern_6_protocol_security.water_use_case: Modbus protocol vulnerabilities in water SCADA systems
pattern_6_protocol_security.energy_use_case: DNP3 protocol vulnerabilities in power systems

validation_rules.description: Validation rules for ensuring schema compliance across sectors
before_import: All 8 core node types must be defined
Common relationship types must be documented
Multi-label rules must be testable (4-8 labels)
Gold standard metrics must be achievable
Cross-sector patterns must be applicable to both Water and Energy
Query patterns must work on sample data
Node IDs must be globally unique
All vulnerability CVEs must be traceable
during_import: Validate label cardinality (4-8 labels per node)
Check for orphaned nodes (nodes without relationships)
post_import: Run cross-sector query patterns against populated graph
Verify node count falls within gold standard range (26000-35000)
Validate relationship density (20-45 edges per node)

quality_checks.consistency: All nodes follow multi-label hierarchy pattern

registry_usage_guidelines.purpose: This registry serves as the authoritative schema template for all 16 critical infrastructure sectors
application: Use Water sector patterns as reference for liquid/fluid infrastructure sectors
Use Energy sector patterns as reference for power/electrical infrastructure sectors
Adapt label patterns while maintaining core structure (NodeType:Specific:Domain:Monitoring:SECTOR:Subsector)
Maintain 4-8 label rule across all sectors
Ensure VULNERABLE_TO relationships dominate security tracking
Apply cross-sector query patterns for consistent analysis across sectors
extension_rules: New sectors must define subsector breakdown (minimum 2 subsectors)
New sectors must identify primary node types (minimum 5 types)
New sectors must document specialized node types unique to domain
New sectors must maintain relationship density in range of 20-45 edges/node
New sectors must achieve 26000-35000 total nodes for comprehensive coverage

metadata.next_update: Upon completion of additional sector extractions
